1.brief: to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint
to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
chastisement; figuratively (by words) correction, refutation, proof (even in defence)
properly, foot (as consumed); i.e. (by exten.) of cattle brutishness; (concretely) stupid

2.brief: good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
to issue, i.e. furnish; causatively, to secure; figuratively, to succeed
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
a plan, usually evil (machination), sometimes good (sagacity)
to be (causatively, do or declare) wrong; by implication, to disturb, violate

3.brief: not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

properly, to be erect (i.e. stand perpendicular); hence (causatively) to set up, in a great variety of applications, whether literal (establish, fix, prepare, apply), or figurative (appoint, render sure, proper or prosperous)
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
properly, a failure; by implication nothing; usually (adverb) not at all; also lest
to waver; by implication, to slip, shake, fall

4.brief: probably a force, whether of men, means or other resources; an army, wealth, virtue, valor, strength
a master; hence, a husband, or (figuratively) owner (often used with another noun in modifications of this latter sense)
a bone (as strong); by extension, the body; figuratively, the substance, i.e. (as pron.) selfsame
properly, to pale, i.e. by implication to be ashamed; also (by implication) to be disappointed or delayed

5.brief: a contrivance, i.e. (concretely) a texture, machine, or (abstractly) intention, plan (whether bad, a plot; or good, advice)

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style
(only in plural) properly, steerage (as a management of ropes), i.e. (figuratively) guidance or (by implication) a plan
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person

6.brief: a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
blood (as that which when shed causes death) of man or an animal; by analogy, the juice of the grape; figuratively (especially in the plural) bloodshed (i.e. drops of blood)
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to
to snatch away, whether in a good or a bad sense

7.brief: to turn about or over; by implication, to change, overturn, return, pervert
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
to stand, in various relations (literal and figurative, intransitive and transitive)

8.brief: the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to
to be clear (orig. of sound, but usually of color); to shine; hence, to make ashow, to boast; and thus to be (clamorously) foolish; to rave; causatively, to celebrate; also to stultify
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)

9.brief: good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
to be light (as implied in rapid motion), but figuratively, only (be (causatively, hold) in contempt)
to be heavy, i.e. in a bad sense (burdensome, severe, dull) or in a good sense (numerous, rich, honorable; causatively, to make weighty (in the same two senses)
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)

10.brief: to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)
properly, a dumb beast; especially any large quadruped or animal (often collective)
compassion (in the plural); by extension, the womb (as cherishing the fetus); by implication, a maiden
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person

11.brief: to work (in any sense); by implication, to serve, till, (causatively) enslave, etc.
to sate, i.e. fill to satisfaction (literally or figuratively)
food (for man or beast), especially bread, or grain (for making it)
to run after (usually with hostile intent; figuratively (of time) gone by)
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything

12.brief: morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
a net (for capturing animals or fishes);  afastness or (beseiging) tower
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)

13.brief: the lip (as a natural boundary); by implication, language; by analogy, a margin (of a vessel, water, cloth, etc.)
a noose (for catching animals) (literally or figuratively); by implication, a hook (for the nose)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
to go (causatively, bring) out, in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively, direct and proxim.
tightness (i.e. figuratively, trouble); transitively, a female rival:

14.brief: the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
to sate, i.e. fill to satisfaction (literally or figuratively)

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
treatment, i.e. an act (of good or ill); by implication, service or requital
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again

15.brief: a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
advice; by implication, plan; also prudence

16.brief: a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)
properly, to plump, i.e. fill up hollows; by implication, to cover (for clothing or secrecy)

17.brief: to puff, i.e. blow with the breath or air; hence, to fan (as a breeze), to utter, to kindle (a fire), to scoff
literally firmness; figuratively security; morally fidelity

properly, to front, i.e. stand boldly out opposite; by implication (causatively), to manifest; figuratively, to announce (always by word of mouth to one present); specifically, to expose, predict, explain, praise
the right (natural, moral or legal); also (abstractly) equity or (figuratively) prosperity
concretely, a witness; abstractly, testimony; specifically, a recorder, i.e. prince
an untruth; by implication, a sham (often adverbial)

18.brief: there is or are (or any other form of the verb to be, as may suit the connection)
to babble; hence, to vociferate angrily
drought; also a cutting instrument (from its destructive effect), as a knife, sword, or other sharp implement
the tongue (of man or animals), used literally (as the instrument of licking, eating, or speech), and figuratively (speech, an ingot, a fork of flame, a cove of water)
properly, curative, i.e. literally (concretely) a medicine, or (abstractly) a cure; figuratively (concretely) deliverance, or (abstractly) placidity

19.brief: the lip (as a natural boundary); by implication, language; by analogy, a margin (of a vessel, water, cloth, etc.)

properly, to be erect (i.e. stand perpendicular); hence (causatively) to set up, in a great variety of applications, whether literal (establish, fix, prepare, apply), or figurative (appoint, render sure, proper or prosperous)
properly, a (peremptory) terminus, i.e. (by implication) duration, in the sense of advance or perpetuity (substantially as a noun, either with or without a preposition)
as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
properly, to toss violently and suddenly (the sea with waves, the skin with boils); figuratively (in a favorable manner) to settle, i.e. quiet; specifically, to wink (from the motion of the eye-lids)
the tongue (of man or animals), used literally (as the instrument of licking, eating, or speech), and figuratively (speech, an ingot, a fork of flame, a cove of water)
an untruth; by implication, a sham (often adverbial)

20.brief: the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything

to scratch, i.e. (by implication) to engrave, plough; hence (from the use of tools) to fabricate (of any material); figuratively, to devise (in a bad sense); hence (from the idea of secrecy) to be silent, to let alone; hence (by implication) to be deaf (as an accompaniment of dumbness)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
to advise; reflexively, to deliberate or resolve
safe, i.e. (figuratively) well, happy, friendly; also (abstractly) welfare, i.e. health, prosperity, peace

21.brief: not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to approach; hence, to meet in various senses
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
strictly nothingness; also trouble. vanity, wickedness; specifically an idol
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to fill or (intransitively) be full of, in a wide application (literally and figuratively)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)

22.brief: properly, something disgusting (morally), i.e. (as noun) an abhorrence; especially idolatry or (concretely) an idol
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
the lip (as a natural boundary); by implication, language; by analogy, a margin (of a vessel, water, cloth, etc.)
an untruth; by implication, a sham (often adverbial)
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
literally firmness; figuratively security; morally fidelity

23.brief: ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
properly, to plump, i.e. fill up hollows; by implication, to cover (for clothing or secrecy)
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly
to call out to (i.e. properly, address by name, but used in a wide variety of applications)

24.brief: a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
properly, incised or (active) incisive; hence (as noun masculine or feminine) a trench (as dug), gold (as mined), a threshing-sledge (having sharp teeth); (figuratively) determination; also eager
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
properly, a burden (as causing to faint), i.e. a tax in the form of forced labor

25.brief: the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
to depress, i.e. prostrate (especially reflexive, in homage to royalty or God)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
probably to brighten up, i.e. (figuratively) be (causatively, make) blithe or gleesome

26.brief: to meander (causatively, guide) about, especially fortrade or reconnoitring
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to vacillate, i.e. reel or stray (literally or figuratively); also causative of both

27.brief: not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to braid (i.e. to entangle or snare) or catch (game) in anet
the chase; also game (thus taken); (generally) lunch (especially for a journey)
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
properly, incised or (active) incisive; hence (as noun masculine or feminine) a trench (as dug), gold (as mined), a threshing-sledge (having sharp teeth); (figuratively) determination; also eager

28.brief: a well-trodden road (literally or figuratively); also a caravan
rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
death (natural or violent); concretely, the dead, their place or state (hades); figuratively, pestilence, ruin
